title: What Credit Score Do You Need to Rent a Home?
seoTitle: Credit Score Needed to Rent a Home
summary: Worried your credit score will hold you back from renting? Here's what landlords really look for, what to do if your score is low, and tips to get approved for housing with less-than-perfect credit.

body.raw:
## Introduction Looking for a new place to live but worried about your credit score? You’re not alone. Many renters fear being denied housing because of bad or limited credit — but the reality is more flexible than you might think. While landlords do consider your credit, it's only **one piece of the puzzle**. There are ways to rent even with low or no credit — and smart steps you can take to improve your chances. *** ## What Credit Score Do Landlords Look For? There’s no single “pass or fail” credit score required to rent — but here are some general trends: - **Above 700**: Strong score — usually no issues - **620–699**: Fair score — often accepted with good income or rental history - **Below 620**: Risk zone — may need extra documentation or a co-signer Some landlords use your full credit report to look at **payment history, collections, or debt**, not just your score. Corporate apartment complexes tend to be stricter than private landlords. ## Can You Rent with No Credit or Bad Credit? Yes — but it depends on the situation. Here are some ways to improve your chances: - **Offer a larger security deposit** - **Provide proof of income or savings** - **Use a co-signer or guarantor** - **Share references from past landlords** - **Write a letter of explanation** (especially after medical bills or job loss) Programs like [rent reporting](./how-paying-rent-can-boost-your-credit-score) can also help build credit over time. If you’re facing a housing crisis or denial, check if you're eligible for [Emergency Rental Assistance](./emergency-rental-assistance-what-it-is-and-how-to-apply-before-it-s-gone) or [Section 8](./section-8-housing-explained-how-to-get-help-paying-rent). ## What Landlords Really Care About Most landlords are looking for **reliable, financially stable tenants**. That often includes: - Steady monthly income (usually 2–3× the rent) - On-time payment history (rent, loans, or utilities) - Clean or explainable background check - Good communication and references Credit score is a factor — but not always the dealbreaker people assume. ## Tips to Improve Approval Odds If you're applying to rent with less-than-perfect credit: - **Apply to independent landlords**: They're more flexible than property managers - **Be honest**: A clear explanation of your credit history shows responsibility - **Fix errors fast**: Dispute incorrect items at [AnnualCreditReport.com](https://www.annualcreditreport.com) - **Build credit proactively**: Tools like secured cards or rent reporting can help > 💡 **Tip:** You don’t need perfect credit to rent — you just need to show that you’ll pay on time. Landlords want good tenants, not perfect numbers. *** ###### References
